I am going to toss an idea in here for people to tear through:

1. Subnet Owners get paid out in TAO rather than Alpha. (They can purchase alpha to support TAO liquidity)
2. Coldkey Swap for Owner key locks Alpha for 30 Days.
So the subnet owner would cause selling pressure on their subnet like root prop? 😅

If you want them to earn TAO, it would need to go through the pool (ALPHA owner cut being unstaked for TAO)

I want a change where owners are paid out in TAO without impacting the alpha price.

That defeats the purpose of my proposal.
The fundamental issue that it is a single pool for everyone. Subnet owners either suffer or the rug.
Sorry, thinking out loud 😂
To understand it better, what's the motivation behind it. Why should owners not get ALPHA but TAO, or why should owners not use the same pool etc.
if you decouple the TAO from the single pool for subnet owners then they can pay their bills and bring some of that TAO into the pool by increasing liquidity.
Also you have an opportunity to avoid accumulation of subnet owner alpha which then can be used to "rug" the subnet when it is being resold.
hence SN46 incident.
And many more to come.
If the owner stake TAO to get ALPHA every epoch they get rewarded, they could still accumulate ALPHA in a similar manner
sure , but you will have more TAO im the pool as well.
More TAO and less Alpha
That's not different for miners, why only pay the owner with TAO
because subnet owners suffer the most in this case, they are not allowed to sell any alpha without negatively impacting the subnet.
subnet always always try to represent the best interests of the miners and validators, but we have bills to pay as well.
and if we cannot secure external revenue - this becomes a slippery slope.

How exactly? Miners have the same  issue, if not arguably a bigger one depending on the subnet, because they are running the "beefy" machines for the task, have to pay their bills still, and the sum is 41% of ALPHA emissions, owners just selling some of their 18% get doesn't seems like an issue in comparison to me

It's up for the owners, miners, validators to find the most cost-effective way, so that they don't need to be selling too much of their emissions, so that they don't create too much selling pressure

That's the "point" of DTAO, you can't have a subnet be successful where everyone just dumps

These are trading grounds.

We are too concerned about the alpha price then actually focusing ond eveloping solid products.
Because all people care about is whether they can anticipate the price of your token going up or going down.

ICO and new coin every other day on bitcointalk forums.
I am venting a bit on this. It is rough.
Many of us are genuinely trying to build something here and the market distracts, as people are being people.

You know dTao better than many out here, so I appreciate your input, genuinely.

Just sharing my thoughts, would be nice to see others add their input 👍

* The most important priority for dTAO, by far, is to maximize the chances of legitimate projects succeeding.

* If subnet (SN) owners earn TAO directly, any cash-out won’t negatively impact investors. Additionally, a 3-day lock on transfers out would give the community time to assess whether a project owner might be attempting to abandon the project and act accordingly

* The scheme can be phased: for example, it could start with owners receiving 100% Alpha now and gradually transition to 100% TAO over the course of one year. Throughout this period, a 3-day lock on transfer-outs and unstaking would apply, giving the community time to assess and respond if needed.

this is the big issue when coldkey swaps happen. you already have an existing alpha supply. so it almost functions like a pre-sale. because people dump their tao into the pool for alpha, increasing the price. but now the market value of the "pre-coldkey swap" holders' stakes have increased significantly. so if they sell their alpha, they are essentially taking out all the tao you just put in. it's a stake-to-reserve system. high stake value (high tao value of a_out) with low reserve (low amount of tao in the pool) is what can lead to bank runs. this is why I don't like the concept of coldkey swaps, as it goes against fair launch principles, and the risk of a rug is very high. I was honestly surprised it didn't happen with sn14 for example. if you understand how the system works, it's pretty easy to manipulate

regarding burns, 

burns are not good long-term. you need liquidity if you want a sustainable price. as the price is just the ratio of tao per alpha in the pool. limit speculation, and factor in a handful of nominators + sn owner selling, and the price crashes, causing emissions to crash with it

yeah this is the point of dTAO. you can sell everything technically, but selling now has consequences, because you are reducing the value of your token the more you sell, forcing you to keep at least some of what you earn. that's the basic idea behind it. everyone gets to determine the emissions for the subnet, and conviction plays an important role

taohash broke everyone's brains, myself included, when it shot up to the top 10 overnight. soon after, lots of users immediately began scrambling to find the "next taohash". sent the market into a frenzy, where unknown subnets began climbing the leaderboard for absolutely no reason other than pure speculation. with this kind of game, some people win, but the vast majority of people lose

this kind of behavior is still prevalent. it's why sn5 is in the top 10, even though it's not active and we have no idea what its purpose is. it only sits at the top because the market knows that latent owns it. once the subnet is announced, will it be a "buy the rumor, sell the news" event? maybe. it's a trap that only exists due to the existing alpha supply and greed

when you're staking on root, everyone wins in the sense that we're all getting tao divs from the chain. a whale can't manipulate the pool and crash the price, because it is static

alpha tokens, long-term, are supposed to operate in a similar manner. the price can never be static, but ideally it stabilizes at some level e.g. 0.1, 0.08, etc. from there, it's mostly about enjoying the divs you earn from the subnet(s) you support. it would look no different than normal tao staking. 

we have a long way to go before we get to this stage, but you can already start to see this kind of behavior with sn64, sn51, and others. the alpha price action is boring, but the tao value of the divs you earn is (currently) around 10x what you'd earn on root. and the discrepancy grows even larger as root proportion decreases. this is what dTAO is supposed to look like. rewarding conviction and genuine support, instead of gambling

to those looking to buy alpha tokens from relatively unknown subnets, with the alpha supply already in the millions, don't let greed cloud your judgement. it's called high-risk, high-reward for a reason. for every winner in the short-term speculation game, there are dozens of losers on the other side

it's a really dangerous game where you can 10x your tao or lose all of it

it's better to be risk-averse and wait a little while, so that you can learn more about the subnet and the team. and then make an informed decision before buying. in other words, frontrunning the market has major consequences, one way or the other

Hi everyone. 
I’ve been following the discussion over the past several days and would like to share my perspective as someone actively involved in the Bittensor ecosystem and deeply familiar with how subnets operate from the inside

I’m firmly against burning miner emissions, and here’s why

First of all, miners are not just abstract wallet addresses – they are teams investing real money and resources. In Subnet 68, for example, we were spending over $200,000 per month on infrastructure, development, and maintaining a high-quality model. These expenses were justified by our ability to earn emissions and sustain operations. But then, the subnet owner decided to burn 80% of miner emissions. As a result, we could no longer support the team, had to shut down all development, and abandon a product we had been actively building. This isn’t theory – it’s a real case

Second, the argument that “burning is better than giving emissions to dead subnets” is weak. Yes, subnets without a functioning task shouldn’t receive emissions – but that doesn’t justify cutting emissions from those who are actively building. We’re trying to solve one problem by creating another, much worse one. Because if today 30–40% of subnets are burning emissions, soon it’ll be 60–70%, and eventually, all will start burning. That will lead to a situation where miners receive nothing anywhere, and Bittensor – as an AI network – simply stops existing. Burn will result in an equilibrium where no one earns anything – which is effectively the same as NOT burning at all

Third – the fact that non-functional subnets still receive emissions is something even supporters of burn have acknowledged. But if that’s the issue, we need to solve that – not penalize the subnets that are actually working. My proposal is to introduce a minimal requirement (MVP) before a subnet can start receiving emissions. For example:
1. The subnet must have a public GitHub repository
2. It must include a basic solution for future miners

Until these conditions are met, the subnet should not be eligible to receive emissions. That’s a much more balanced and fair approach than cutting rewards from teams who are already contributing to the ecosystem

Another point: burn is often presented as a way to control tokenomics. But in reality, it’s a temporary illusion of control. No subnet has seen long-term alpha price growth because of burning. The ones that grow are those that build actual products and engage with their communities

My position is clear: burn should either be removed entirely or turned into a strictly regulated tool, with clear time limits and governance participation from miners, owners, and validators

it's very hard to track something that are not on-chain. The solution to SNs who abuse the "burn miner emissions" mechanism, is quite trival. YC can auto-detect it, and after that the emissions protocol will auto-sell it as currently root proportion works. If such mechanism to be implemented, the burn subnets going to  capitulate

If we’re building a decentralized system, then let’s actually use the blockchain for this.

Right now, it’s concerning that a single individual – the subnet owner – can unilaterally decide how much alpha miners receive. 

In this setup, miners have no real guarantees. They can invest time, money, and effort – but still have their rewards reduced or even removed, not because of poor performance, but just because the subnet owner decided so.

To fix this, we need clear on-chain rules, a basic MVP requirement before emissions start, and a way for the community to review whether a subnet is active or not. That would make the system more fair – and more aligned with the decentralized principles Bittensor is supposed to follow.

Originally, the Bittensor founders allocated 41% of emissions to miners. That alone signals how important miners were intended to be in the system.

In traditional terms, that’s like holding 41% of the shares in a company. But imagine a situation where, despite holding such a stake, your earnings could be reduced or taken away at any moment – without your input, and without any formal process.

Is that fair? Does it reflect the value miners bring to the Bittensor?

If miners are meant to be core participants, the system should offer predictability and protection, not leave them fully exposed to unilateral decisions by subnet owners.

The BIT's motivation:
> Upon release, subnets with advanced requirements may be affected by low-quality miners as their talent pool is still developing. assume the sum is under 1, so every subnet's price < emissions

chutes has a price of 0.05. emissions is 0.1

you have 10 tao and decide to buy 200 sn64 tokens. worth 10 tao right now

due to upwards convergence, and assuming chutes can maintain its % of the sum, the price of chutes will inevitably be pushed back up by the chain. because it's 0.05 tao per alpha in the pool, versus 0.1 tao per alpha being injected into the pool via the chain. the injection pressure pushes the price back towards emissions

Miners (and me in particular) are concerned not only about TAO but also about whether their efforts, expenses, and energy to support the subnet are justified. If a team of miners knows that the subnet won’t suddenly cut emissions by 75% in one sunny day just because it’s convenient for the owner, they will invest in long-term solutions that can pay off in a month or even longer.

But if a miner is put in a position where they must rely on the mercy of the subnet owner—who can decide at any moment to burn any amount of emissions—they’ll only care about extracting as much TAO as possible, even exploitative ones, before they themselves get f*cked with emission cut.

Everyone benefits from miners being confident that emissions won’t suddenly start being burned — subnet owners, who then get workers building for the future; users, who receive truly functional solutions; and the subnet owner too, unless of course, he only thinks about keeping his subnet’s token price up by any means, even at the expense of the product, ignoring miners and the users of his product.

There will be much more stability once subnet owners — who are often just random dudes with little interest in Bittensor’s overall economy — take away the tool that allows them to cut miner's emissions by their own rules. 

Their rules often conflict with what would make Bittensor more stable and reliable for both product users and strong miners, who always work toward long-term results that might only pay off after 1–2 months

Thanks for your thoughtful reply — I agree that nominators take real risk by locking TAO, and both sides (miners and nominators) deserve fair reward.
That said, burning miner emissions is fundamentally harmful to the ecosystem. Here's why:
1) Miners can’t adapt as easily as nominators
Nominators can quickly move capital. Miners spend weeks building infra, training models, and tuning solutions. Sudden burn wipes that out and punishes real effort.
2) Burning breaks the service-reward link
Miners provide the actual value — without them, alpha is just empty. Burning emissions while keeping their work undermines trust and kills incentives.
3) There are better solutions than burn
Want to reduce sell pressure? Try delayed emissions, vesting, or better task validation. Burn is just a shortcut that drives out honest contributors.
Miners and nominators are co-dependent. Let's reward both — not create systems where one thrives at the expense of the other.

The alpha price should not be tied to anything, it should be free like a meme token, and the addition of a new emission should occur without changing the price at any alpha cost and only add liquidity.

What bothers me the most is that a lack of effort is being rewarded.

A subnet can hang a sign saying "closed, we'll be back later" (by enabling emission burning), quietly continue developing its codebase, and eventually release - all while its TAO in Pool and Alpha in Pool grow more or less proportionally, keeping it in roughly the same position as when the burning was enabled.
Meanwhile, subnets that evolve openly and improve their solutions through constant interaction with miners face a gradual reduction in emissions.
In other words, subnets that don’t burn emissions are taking a risk (knowingly or not), and they get punished for it.
Clearly, punishing initiative is the way to progress.

Let’s summarize:

1. Miners are at a loss due to burn.


2. Subnet owners (SO) are at a loss because they can’t sell alpha, otherwise their subnet dies.


3. Validators keep earning as before.


4. Subnets are in conflict with each other.


5. SOs are now positioned against miners.


6. Only about 25–30% of subnets have real development now behind them (and don’t tell me about subnets offering cheap compute — they just drain the other half of the funds via TAO).


7. TAO price hasn’t exceeded pre-DTAO levels.


8. Burn-based “empty” projects show more stable emissions, while product-focused subnets collapse much harder.



Before DTAO:

1. The community was actively growing.


2. Miners were building and confident in the future (psychological stability significantly affects work quality).


3. SOs were earning and promoting their networks while improving their tasks.


4. Validators were also earning.


5. Validators allocated more emissions to stronger projects (yes, with flaws — but those were addressed by the community).

Let me clarify again.
Let’s say staking yield in a subnet is 15%.
If that subnet burns 66% of the total emission, then the staking yield drops to 5%.
In that case, it’s more profitable for stakers to move to subnets without burn.

This could create a snowball effect where even miners stop selling, hoping for further price increases.

In a start up, you experiment, invest, and repeat if things are unsuccessful. The reality is we are using stone age tools for managing spend. Typically miners aggregate more towards the "infra" side of spend - we have CI/CD/kubernetes/devops to spin machines up and down in the real world - arguably burns (and dynamic burns) are abstractions about that.

Owners have to be sure the production is creating real economic value - in a world where the "treasure chest" never empties, sure, if you're not spending, your project is broken. The reality is owners are responsible for spending investors funds (including TAO rewards) to further the protocol.

> @Fish | lium.io has quite accurately said we need slashing, or better tools to promote good work.

Fish also mentioned that good work should correlate with revenue and return on investment from the subnet itself.

It's easy to say "let's slash." I'm personally in favor of slashing validators who don't do their jobs yes, but **who controls the slashing**? Right now, no party in **Bittensor** is fully neutral or agnostic.

**99% of contributors** wear multiple hats — **owning**, **validating**, **mining**.

So how do we avoid **manipulation** in slashing?

I understand the need to penalize miners when appropriate, but in Lium's case, for example — if Fish is the **owner**, the **miner**, and also the **validator** — it becomes very easy to control the alpha and influence Tao emissions.

Take another example: Targon raised millions without releasing any **open-source** output.

This seems to contradict Bittensor's core principles of decentralization.

As for the claim that "miners are dumping everything," that’s also a bit of an oversimplification.

> Go look at owner wallets, very few have sold the same fraction as miners

The same goes for validators. Many have sold heavily in the past, often while just replicating weights without meaningful contribution.
I’m enabling MUV in WC now for subnets that truly deserve it.

The initial system was designed for miners to cover their costs, just like owners have their 18% share and validators have their cut.
In theory, validators shouldn’t earn less unless they are not truly validating.

In my opinion, **miners**, **validators**, and **owners** should all be **holders**.
What makes people dump isn’t just the tokenomics — it’s the lack of **production**, **revenue**, and **stability** in the subnet. If a team isn’t delivering results or showing strong output, investors will lose confidence and **sell**.

As a miner, what pushed me to sell? Not just *GPU costs* — it was poor subnet design and underperformance by some teams.

Some validators earn disproportionately while contributing little, whereas at MUV, we've tried to be transparent, fair, and honest — yet we didn't receive really a proportional share. That’s another systemic issue with no easy fix.

**Everyone’s frustrated**, but this is just **market regulation** at work.
Trying to justify unfair mechanisms is a mistake — they should never have been implemented.

If your subnet can’t handle miner sell pressure, maybe it’s not ready yet.
We’ve spent a year dealing with subnets lacking productivity, while miners constantly find exploits or build solutions within hours or days.

Miners are doing their part. That can’t just be dismissed.
Meanwhile, Fish has burned all miner emissions while receiving over 5% of Tao emissions for months, and benefiting from the tao_in pool.

I don’t have a perfect solution. But as **Const** himself said: don’t invest too early — wait for the market to regulate itself, then put resources into real alpha.

As of now, it’s clear that Chutes bears the highest operational costs for miners.
Miners there are selling to pay for infrastructure — but many also choose to hold. Why? Because the product is strong, and the team has invested heavily themselves to push the alpha to its current level.
However they don't have any burn in place. 
Having this showed off. How could you justify a single second to burn > 50% of miners supply ?

Life isn’t easy.
Neither is Bittensor.

```
# dTAO Emission Notes (updated)

tao_in = (EMA price / sum of EMA prices) * TAO block emission
alpha_in = tao_in / price

- When price < tao_in:
    → alpha_in > max(a_in)
    → scale alpha_in down to max(a_in)

- When price > tao_in:
    → alpha_in < max(a_in)
    → use alpha_in as-is

- max(a_in) = alpha block emission

- TAO block emission:
    → starts at 1
    → decreases over time with each TAO halving: 0.5, 0.25, etc.

- alpha block emission:
    → starts at 1
    → decreases over time with each alpha halving: 0.5, 0.25, etc.
```

It works like this @goalman 

Every block Bittensor mints 1 TAO and splits it across the subnets. For instance, Chutes gets 11.82%    emission or 0.1182 TAO per block minted into it's liquidity pool. 

At the same time that this TAO is minted and injected the chain also mints a price proportional amount of ALPHA, i.e. chutes's token and injects it into the pool. This price proportional amount of ALPHA is specifically emission/price or in Chutes case, 0.1182/0.130468 where 0.13 is the current TAO per ALPHA Chutes price.

dTAO Emission Notes (updated based on the new logic https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/830075335084474390/1399903146276290681 )

```
# dTAO Emission Notes (updated)

tao_in = (EMA price / sum of EMA prices) * TAO block emission
alpha_in = tao_in / price

- When price < tao_in:
    → alpha_in > max(a_in)
    → scale alpha_in down to max(a_in)
    → "new" tao_in = price * TAO block emission (This amount is what is added to the pool)
    → The chain uses the remaining TAO (tao_in - "new" tao_in) to buy alpha, and that alpha is subsequently recycled
    → The alpha that root would have sold, based on root proportion, instead gets burned, when price < tao_in

- When price > tao_in:
    → alpha_in < max(a_in)
    → use alpha_in as-is

- max(a_in) = alpha block emission

- TAO block emission:
    → starts at 1
    → decreases over time with each TAO halving: 0.5, 0.25, etc.

- alpha block emission:
    → starts at 1
    → decreases over time with each alpha halving: 0.5, 0.25, etc.
```

The downscaling/buy mechanism only happens on a subnet that has a lower price than TAO emissions. If it happens on subnet X it will not affect subnet Y at all. Also the buying will have a lower impact on price on subnets with a higher pool liquidity, but then also those wouldn't decrease in price as much, relatively speaking it should be usually quite similar

It has an impact on subnet prices, because imagine the scenario where all prices would now effectively drop so that the sum of prices would be below 1, while the % emission stay same, because the price proportions to sum of prices remained. Because the prices would be now all below their emissions all the prices would trigger the downscaling/buy mechanism and thus their prices would increase until the sum of prices would be back to 1. The reason is because the chain "has" to emit 1 TAO across all subnets, and for this mechanism not to trigger the sum of prices has to then be above the sum of TAO emissions (so above 1.0 after the TAO halving above 0.5)

Fox, thank you — it’s from you that I first heard about how emission burning can actually be useful for “burning out” a subnet.

The following text isn’t an contrargument, but rather a look at the same problem from the miners’ perspective, with full understanding of your actual situation.

In your case it looks like you knew from the start how much spending would be needed and burned emissions right away. There’s value in that for your business and also for miners, because they can work here long-term as long as the business keeps going. But in other subnets it happens that the owner hypes up their “product” a bit (like a Google review parser) and then tells all the miners to take a hike, cutting emissions by 75% with the explanation (quote): “we had to enable it to control inflation.”

Problem: For miners, the pressing and unfair issue is that a subnet owner can burn emissions on any given day without any restrictions. If a subnet declares from the start that it will burn 50% of emissions, miner teams can do their calculations based on that and decide whether it works for them or not. But if a subnet owner can start burning emissions at will, rolling it out as yet another “update” on Discord, then — in addition to the volatility of alpha and the TAO token — miners (and only miners) face a very real (and recently increasing) risk that tomorrow (or in a week or two — nobody knows) their earnings could be slashed by 50–70–90% for the same amount of work.

Solution: So the solution would be either to remove the ability to burn emissions after a certain period of time — or require a one-month notice before any burn is applied.


* 
As for dishonest miners from your next message — absolutely, if I were the subnet owner, I would ban them and kick from Bittensor : ) But unlike miners, who have no way to influence emission burning, a subnet owner does have ways to deal with unfair miners — from optimizing incentive mechanisms to outright banning them by key.

But with a prior warning in Discord to everyone who plans to break the rules, explaining exactly which exploits you will start banning people for after the next update — and why those rules shouldn’t be broken (for the sake of the subnet’s future)

A newbe but good example is the Fair Policy in subnet 122. They explained what they would ban for and why — and no one felt the urge to scream about unfairness )
